PAGE TWO

ODK Events Suspend Classes
Student Couurtcil Forbids Annual Class Rivalry
Any Camp-us Kidnaping To Spark Class Day
Kidnapping practices on the
entire Homewood campus were
forbidden by the Student Council in a sweeping decision at
Tuesday's meeting.
A motion to forbid kidnapping
In the dormitories was stated by
Dave Adams and was subsequently amended to include
the entire campus.
The discussion concerning kidnapping was prefaced by a report by Interfraternity Board
President Al Powgermaker in
which he expressed the opinions
put forth by the IFB fraternities
at their Friday meeting. Powdermaker stated that the IFB voted
11-0, with 2 abstentions, in favor
of permitting the continuation of
kidnapping practices.
Three Kidnap
He said that the Board felt
that although only three fraternities—Phi Ep, Beta and DU-still hold kidnapping policies, any
Infringement upon this practice
would necessarily restrict the
freedom of fraternities in the

handling of their pledges as they
see fit. He added that if the Student Council wanted to rule
against kidnapping it would be
"another thing." "It would be impossible to rule out kidnapping
altogether." Powdermaker further
stated that he thought it would
be a good idea to forbid kidnapping in the dorms.
Stu Hanlein, a principal proponent of curbs on kidnapping,
stated the case for the DSRC, of
which he is president. He said,
"what fraternities do with their
pledges is their own business unless they disturb others. I've
lived in the dorms for four years
and I would like quiet. We are
trying to make the dormitory a
home away from home for the
on-campus boys. We can help
100% to make the dorms better
by cutting out kidnapping."
No Respect
"Many fraternity men do not
live in the dormitories," continued Hanlein, "and therefore
have no respect for the dormitory

equipment, property, or quiet.

told to." "Last Monday there

Sophomore representative Joel cron Delta Kappa
Lench stated that he felt that
this is an individual fraternity
matter if they want to take the
chance. He said that kidnapping
doesn't make that much of a
commotion—certainly no more
than the usual commotion of
dormitory life. He added that
this is a "slap in the face of the
fraternities—it's impossible to
study in the dorms anyway."

Goucher, Hopkins Groups
Meet, Eat, Talk, Propose
After enjoying a meal consisting of chicken, tossed salad,
broccoli, rice and blueberry pie,
six Hopkins student leaders and
Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, Dean of
Students, sat down with a similar
Goucher contingent to discuss
matters relating to the proposed
coordinated program of cultural,
social and academic activities between the two schools.
Attending for Hopkins were
Bill DeVoe, president of the Student Council; Mau Miyasaki,
chairman of the Student Activities Commission; Boland McCamy, president of the YMCA
and ODK; Al Powdermaker,
president of the IFB; Richard
Popp, president of the Cotillion
Board; Andy Silinsh, representing the DSRC; and Dr. Morrill.
Goucher Representatives
From Goucher were Leslie
Pederson, Students Organization
president; Cindy Sharp, Athletic
Association president; Bev Mason, Goucher College Interfaith
Association president; Ronnie
Loeser, Judicial Board chairman;
Flora Fenner, All-College Activities chairman; Jean Lampton
and Debby Jaffe, representatives
of the Social Committee of
Goucher; and Dean Nichols.
The two groups agreed that the
committee which met tonight
was too' large to perform the
daily operations necessary for
the successful functioning of the
program. They therefore decided
that a chairman and an assistant
be elected or appointed through
each school's student government.
Perpetuation Arranged
The chairman will be a senior

Political Speeches
Written By Ghosts
Attacked By Long
Clarence D.*Long, Professor of
Political Eccinomy, recently made
newspaper and television history
by calling for politicians "to
adopt a standard of ethics in
their public appearances which
match those they are demanding
from TV quiz shows" by disclosing 'the ghost writers of their
speeches as well as of the books
that made some of them famous."
Continuing the crusade he began in his bid for the Democratic
nomination for U. S. Senator
last year,- Dr. Long went on to
say that the type of ghost writing he had been attacking was
of the variety which found staff
Writers developing ideas, writing
a statement and then issuing it
to the press often without the
candidate even 'seeing it. Dr.
Long went on to say, "When a
political candidate or elected official reads an impressive speech
on inflation or foreign policy,
how many listeners are aware
that he may be completely
ignorant of the issues and may
have just barely read the speech
that his staff writer handed
him?"
On a TV interview Dr. Long
stated he felt that to an extent
the newspapers were responsible
for not giving this issue a bigger
plug while he was running last
year. He felt the papers should
have given him a little more
"moral support" on these points
When questioned as to his possible candidacy in the future Dr.
Long said, that if Nelson Rockefeller still won't say he is running for anything, he thought it
to be too early; any office he
might seek would not come up
for grabs until 1962. Dr. Long
did indicate, however, that he
was still interested in public office.

Handbook—
The Johns Hopkins YMCA
Cabinet announces the election of officers for the 1960
"Y" Handbook. They are:
editor-in -chief, Harry Lambright; business manager, Rolf
Bessin. The remaining staff
members and section editors
will be .chosen later.

Teachers—
The National Teacher Examinations given by The Educational Testing Service will
be at Johns Hopkins University on Saturday, February 13,
1960.
It will be a one day test in
Which the candidate may take
the Common Examinations,
Which include General Culture, English Expression and
Non-Verbal Reasoning. In addition to this he may take
two of the twelve Optional
Examinations.
Further information may be
found on the Gilman Hall
bulletin boards.

Figures released by the Regis- I
trar's Office show that 1401
undergraduates are attending
Johns Hopkins University this
year, an increase of 34 over last
year's total of 1367. Of the 1401,
765 are in Arts and Sciences, 492
in Engineering, and 144 in Business.
Of 434 Freshman, 241 are in
A. & S. with 19 receiving advanced standing, 164 in Engineering with 10 in advanced
standing, and 29 in business,
with 3 placed in an advance
group. The rest of the 1401 students are upperclassmen. There
are 490 in A. & S., 15 having
returned after an absence, 308
In Engineering, 10 having returned, and 107 in Business,
5 having returned.
12 Left Early

sophomore, and junior classes,
12 entered medical or graduate
school, or were absent on leave

more students withdrew by October 1959 for various reasons.

other institutions, transfer to
McCoy, financial

Must Request Own
The student must request his
own deferment. Miss Davis reported that Johns Hopkins University is not having much
trouble in getting draft deferments.
A Selective Service College
Qualification Test (SSCQT) is
given by the Selective Service
Board to students wishing draft
deferment. Miss Davis advised
all students to take this exam
when they reach draft age. She
said, "A number of draft boards
will consider a student for deferment if he scores high on the
test even if he is low in his
class." This system favors schools
with high standards.

Big Boom Foreseen
In JHU Applicants
By ED MORSE
Applications for admission to
the Johns Hopkins University in
1960 will start a large-cale increase which will continue to
grow during the next ten years,
predicted Mr. Robert Bilgrave,
Director of Admissions, this week.
Since the number of applicants
will soar, while the number of
freshmen admitted will remain
more or less constant, students
will be selected on a more disCriminating basis.
Over the last three years there
has been a 37% increase in the
number of applications. Since
1953 they have doubled. In 1959
over 1800 applications were completed. The major part of the applications were for pre-medical
studies.
Large Increase
The freshman class size has
Increased from 354 in 1957 to
418 in 1959. This increase was
mainly in the social science, humanities and physical science
groups. Entering classes will keep
this size in the future. For each
freshman that entered Hopkins,
the Admissions Office has had
to accept almost two applicants.

In reviewing applications, the
admissions office relies most
heavily on the student's high
school transcript. This includes
his class standing, guidance
counselor recommendation,
teachers' comments and standard test results. An increasingly
important factor in selection is
the applicant's score on the College Entrance Examination.
College Boards Count More
"If an applicant of two years
ago scored low on his College
Entrance Examination, he would
have had a much better chance
for admissions than if he applied now," said Mr. Bilgrave.
Thus, with the increase in the
number of applications, students
at Hopkins will be coming from
a wider geographical area and
also those of greater ability will
be admitted.
Another basis of accepting applicants includes the interview
with an admissions officer. Except for students who are unable to get to see an admissions
officer for an interview,.all students are interviewed before being accepted. Mr. Bilgrave noted

Foreign Speakers Discuss UN 1961 Examination Schedule
At Cosmopolitan Club Soiree To Be Extended Two Days
On Saturday, November 14 the
Cosmopolitan Club presented a
program of four speakers from
foreign countries who discussed
attitudes towards the United Nations in their respective parts
of the world, and specifically in
their country.
The program, which was presented in cooperation with the
United Nations Association of
Maryland, was entitled "The
U.N.'s Impact 'Round the World."
The main speakers were Leslie
Ronald Aldous of the United
Kingdom, Inder Jitt of India.
Bastiaan Klaverstijn of the
Netherlands, Dr. Norberto de
Ramos of the Philippines, and
Luis Zalamea of Columbia.
Mr. Zalamea, who was the
moderator and a representative
of the United Nations Office of
Public Information, did -not act
in behalf of Columbia but rather
for the United Nations. He explained the purpose of the meeting and the purpose of the U.N.
Fellowship program which was
responsible for the Program. The
Program was organized to help
keep the public informed as to
the U.N.'s activities. Its members
are primarily people connected
With the mass media.
Mr. Aldous, who is the Chief
Officer of the
Information
United Nations Association of

the United Kingdom, was the
first member of the panel to
speak. He did not deal directly
with the question at hand but
discussed, rather, what the
United Nations Association was
doing in the United Kingdom,
The U.N.A.'s main problem was
in trying to break down the existing apathy towards the U.N.
Bastiaan Klaverstijn, an Editor for the Netherlands News
Agency, spoke on his country's
contribution to the U.N. and the
U.N.'s contribution to his country. Acording to Mr. Klaverstijn,
the Netherlands is the third
largest contributor of technical
aid to the U.N. He also pointed
that however large the Netherlands economic contribution was,
they nevertheless have a relatively small impact on world
politics. Unfortunately, the writer
had some difficulty in understanding all of Mr. Klaverstijn's
speech.
Dr. Ramos of the Philippines
is an author, commentator, and
professor. At the present time
he is drafting the first text book
on the United Nations. Because
of language difficulties, the
writer missed much of Dr.
Ramos' speech. However, he did
make the point that the U.N.
had helped to build them up and

that they were now helping to
build up less developed countries.
The last speaker was Mr. Jitt
of India, a correspondent for
"The Times of India." Mr. Jitt
noted that the United Nations is
a part of every-day life in India; and that U.N. beliefs concerning the settlement of its
problems are quite similar to
India's. Mr. Jitt ended by saying
that he thought that the "only
hope for man is in the United
Nations."
A short period of questions
and answers followed during
which most of the questions
posed were in reference to Red
China and whether it should be
admitted to the United Nations.
The feeling of the panelists was
that it should be admitted.

The 1961 January examination
schedule has been lengthened
from the present eight-day
period to a ten-day expanse,
announced Miss Irene Davis, registrar of Johns Hopkins University.

The change was made by Miss
Davis in order to avoid three
consecutive examinations and to
include reading time during the
examination 'period. Since the
1959-60 school schedule was completed when these changes were
suggested, they have been initiated in the 1960-61 school year.
The change has been in the
air sinee last fall when a student delegation met with Miss
Davis; Dr. G. Wilson Shaffer;

Dr William K. Morrill; and Dr.
David Danskin. It was then sug•
gested that a change be made in
order to eliminate the occurrence of three consecutive exams
•

on anyone's schedule.
examination
First - semester
period begins Wednesday, Jan'
uary 27, and concludes Thursday, February 4.
The schedule is aranged 131
a block system. For example, the
examination for all classes which
meet at 8 a.m. Monday, TuesdaY
and Wednesday, are scheduled
at the same time. This holds
true for all classes except foreign
mathematics
and
languages
which each have one test for all
students, which all take at one
time.

When William P. Dugan graduated from
State University of Iowa in 1955, he had
a degree in business administration, a
wife, and a firm resolution to get ahead
in business.
Bill went to work with Northwestern
Bell Telephone Company at Des Moines.
"I wanted to work where I'd find real
opportunities for advancement and get
the training necessary to take advantage
of them," he says."I couldn't have made
a better choice."
Ten months of diversified training
taught Bill the "language" of the business
and gave him the know-how and selfassurance he needed. He was transferred
to the Traffic Department at Cedar Rapids
where he gained experience in operating

room procedures, force scheduling and
training and in supervising operating
personnel. He returned to Des Moines
and in February, 1959, was promoted to
District Traffic Supervisor there.
Today, Bill heads up an organization
of ten supervisory people and about 230
telephone operators who handle approximately 42,000 calls each day. He is also
responsible for auxiliary services such as
Information and the Telephone Company
switchboard.
"This is a booming business," says
Bill."There are new problems coming up
every day to keep my job interesting and
challenging. I don't know where a man
can find more genuine opportunities to
improve himself."

Bill Dugan found the career he was looking for
with a Bell Telephone Company. You might find
yours, too. Talk with the Bell interviewer when
he visits your campus—and read the Bell Tele.
phone booklet on file in your Placement Office.

By STEVE VOORHEES

Exclusion Tactics
The role of the college newspaper is, next to that of
the intellectual and the pervert, the most talked-about yet
least understood subject to rue the minds of undergraduates since the days when Sparta U. dropped its first cadet
colonel.
The main criticism levelled against the News-Letter
has been that its editors form judgments "unqualified
due to a lack of understanding of the situation." However,
the very individuals who so readily voice this view are
in many cases those who insist that certain meetings be
closed wherein important policy decisions directly affecting the undergraduates are made.
As these individuals would have it, the campus newspaper should deteriorate into nothing more than a bulletin
board, tilled with press releases issued at their own discretion which neglect any dissenting opinion.
Formal statements by campus organization men have
the texture of a pre-chewed slice of sugared bread.
Self-government cannot be maintained by clandestine
proceedings. If our so-called "self-government" is to rise
above the level of gross travesty it must welcome all interested students.
The News-Letter does recognize the responsibility
which certain campus leaders fail to see themselves—that
of reporting and commenting honestly upon actions which
involve the student body. Their unjudicious exclusion
policies somehow do not gibe with accusations of neglected
integrity.

AMERICAN LITERATURE:
ITS CAUSE AND CURE
Today, as a service to students of American literature, this'
column presents digests of two classic American novels:
TI1E SCARLET LETTER
by Nathaniel-"Swifty" Hawthorne
This is a heart-rending story of a humble New England lass
named Hester Prynne who is so poor that she does not have
what to eat nor a roof to cover her head. But she is a brave,
brawny girl and she never complains, and by and by her
patience is rewarded: in the summer of 1859 she wins a football
scholarship to Alabama.
•
Hard-working Hester soon wins her letter and everyone says
she is a shoo-in for All-Conference honors, but along comes the
'War Between the States and football, alas, is dropped for the
duration.

- --we

R_

„
She?5boolkrill-Wilfrezte1014;

Poor Hester goes back to New England. It is a bitter cold
winter and poor Hester, alas, does not have any warm clothing
except for her football sweater from Alabama, but that, alas,
has a big scarlet"A" on the front of it and she can hardly wear
such a thing in New England where Union sentiment runs so
high.
Poor Hester, alas, freezes td death.
LITTLE WOMEN
by Louisa May "Bubbles" Alcott
The Marches are a very happy family—and for no discernible
reason. They are poor as snakes; they work from cockcrow to
evensong; their dear old father Philip is away with the Union
armies; and they can't do a thing with their hair.
Still, nothing can dampen the spirits of madcap Meg,jocular
Jo, buoyant Beth, animated Amy, and crazy old Marmee, as
the merry March girls laughingly call their lovable mother.
Well sir, one Christmas the March girls get an invitation to a
ball..They are dying to go because they never have any fun at
all except maybe a few chuckles during the hog-rendering
season. But Beth reminds her sisters that,they ,can hardly go
traipsing off to a ball and leave poor Marmee all alone at
Christmas time. The sisters swear a lot, but they finally agree
with Beth.
Marmee, however, will not hear of it. "Land's sakes, little
women!" she cries. "You must go to the ball and have some
fun. There will be fruit punch and Toll -House cookies and
Early American sandwiches. Best of all, there will be. morris
dancing. Oh, how your father and I used to love that!"
"I never knew father could dance," ories Meg.
"Oh yeah?" cries Marmee. "You should have seen Philip
morris."
"Was Philip a good morriser?" cries Jo.
"The best!" cries Maripee. "Philip could morris in soft pack
or flip-top box and was full of fine, fresh, natura) mildness!"
The girls are cheered to hear this and go to the ball. Marmee
stays home alone, but soon gets a wonderful surprise: Philip
conies back from the war!
When the girls return, from the ball, they find Marmee and
Philip morrising, and they cry "Huzzah!" and throw their poke
bonnets in the air, where they are to this day.

Wooded House
Owned By JEW
By NELSON DORSEY
The Evergreen House, a large
rambling brick edifice in a 36acre wooded park, has been a
part of the Johns Hopkins University since 1942. Under the
will of John Work Garrett, the
mansion and the grounds at 4545
North Charles Street, his collection of rare maps, books, pamphlets, coins and medals, Oriental ceramics, and most of his
celebrated collection of autographs were left to Hopkins. It
is maintained by the Evergreen
House Foundation, an educational 'trust set up in 1952 by the
will of Alice,Warder Garrett, as
a research library and mUseum
for the benefit of the University
and the people ,of Baltimore.
The main house, a classical
revival structure, was built in
the 1850's. In 1885 a north wing
was erected, joining the house
by an archway. This part became the Far East Room, where
there has been assembled a fine
oollection of Oriental art objects.
Another part became a handsome
little theatre, where amateur
theatricals were given, or friends
were entertained with music.
New - Library
The most important addition
to the house is the "new library"
at the southeast corner of the
mansion overlooking the Italian
garden. This single, lofty chamber shelters 8,700 choice volumes. There are, elsewhere in
the building, more than 26,000
other volumes, not in the rare
book category, but of wide scOpe
and importance. In one classification of books, this room is of
particular interest to students.
This category is in the room devoted to texts on international
law and diplomacy. It includes
all known official source publicaiions on WOrld War I, one of

the few complete collections of
Marten's Treatises:running more
than 100 volumes, and a complete file of the U.S. State Department's official correspondence from the Revolutionary
War to 1940.
Mr. J. W.. Garrett, a Princeton
graduate and U.S. ambassador,
had four general interests: natural history, items dealing with
the beginnings of Maryland, obtaining the signatures of the
signers of the Declaration of
Independence, and collecting
coins. and medals.
Audubon Collection
In the natural history group,
besides huge Audubons and
Goulds, are the flower paintings
of Redoute, and "Natural History of the Carolinas, Florida,
and Bahamas" printed by Catesby in. London in 1771.-The Maryland collection contains 80 of the 130 books and
pamphlets known to have been
printed about this state before
1700.
Sharing the attention with the
diverse wonders of the house is
the complete collection of signatures of the signers of the Declaration of Independence.
Coini and medals are also well
represented in this house-muThe American group
seum.
stretches from our Colonial beginnings to 1940. Among the
early items are Massachusetts
pine-tree shillings of 1652, the
less-known oak and willow shilling& arid a still earlier shilling,
known to antedate 1652.

Sable, Gold Reign
As School Colors
Over Black, Blue
By JOHN FARNHAM
The Johns Hopkins University
has for almost eighty years been
confused over the issue of school
colors. Newcomers see mostly an
Imaginative black and blue enhancing the athletic teams and
school jackets.
After painfully adapting to
the ferocious Hopkins black-and-

blue jay, one never fails to discover that actually the official
colors are sable and gold.
But logic triumphs, and there
actually exists a traceable pattern of thought by which this
whole mess can be settled. Originally, back at the dawn of the
University it was decided to accept the black and sable from
the Hopkins seal which was an
amalgamation of the Lord Baltimore family's coat of arms
(which the state had already
stolen nefariously) and the symbols of scholarship and All

That's Good: the books and terrestial globe.
This was a fine arrangement
for all, until one day during a
Hopkins-Princeton athletic event
—some sort of medieval game
played in those less civilized days
before the invention of modern
non-violent sports—the officials
discovered that no one knew who
was winning or even which team
was going which way. Princetonorange and Hopkins-sable blended rather well, and it was common to see many traumatized
spectators leaving the games.
From this it is easy to see that
the logical change would be from
sable to blue. The Hopkins men
suddenly appeared in black and
blue horizontally-striped jerseys.
This temporarily ended the problems, but someone soon realized
that the new color scheme 'was
closely related to that of the
convicts at the Maryland penitentiary, and the police were on
occasions being completely undone.
-Next vertical stripes were
tested, but this solution became
invalidated with the creation of
referees. By this time nobody
gave a damn what the colors
were. Psychotic color blindness
was a fad.

Milton Gains Post
On US Committee
To Advise Dwight
Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower,
President of the Johns Hopkins
University and expert on Latinaffairs, has been
American
named to an important National
Advisory Committee on InterAmerican Affairs by the President of the United States.
Dr. Eisenhower will serve on
the six-man committee under
the chairmanship of Secretary
of State Christian A. Herter.
In announcing the appointments, President Dwight D.
Eisenhower stated that the committee's creation should serve as
"tangible evidence of the imUnited
the
which
portance
States attaches to relations with
the other American Republics."
Valuable Function
A White House statement released simultaneously said the
President had expressed his conviction that the new committee
"would perform a very helpful
function both in terms of developing useful ideas with re,spect to our Inter-American
Relations and in promoting wider
understanding of these relation§
among the peoples of this country."
Serving on the committee in
addition to Dr. Eisenhower will
be: Walter J. Donnelly, former
t. S. Ambassador to Venezuela
and an executive at the U. S.
in. South
Steel Corporation
America; G. Kenneth Holland.
president of the Institute of International Education; G. A.
Knight, a vice-president of the
AFL-CIO and president of the
Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union; Charles
A. Meyer, a vice-president of
Sears, Roebuck Co.; and Dr.
Dana G. Munro, director of the
Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at
Princeton University.
Miltie's Recommendation
President Eisenhower's authorization of an advisory group
carries out a recommendation of
Dr. Eisenhower in a report following a tour of Latin American
contries .at the President's request last year.
The White House stated that
the committee is in no way related to the current wave of
anti-United States sentiment in
Cuba and Panama, nor the wave
of outbreaks there and throughout Latin America.

By LEWIS II. SIEGEL, Sports Editor
It is fitting that the diamond anniversary of football
at Hopkins should be marked by what must be considered
One of the greatest grid squads in that long seventy-five
Year history.
Having clinched the Southern Division Mid-Atlantic
Conference title and set a new school scoring mark with
last week's 47-0 victory over Dickinson, the Jays have
an outside chance to add the Mason-Dixon title to their
laurels with a victory over Western Maryland tomorrow.
The league situation is rather complicated, with four
teams all having a shot at the crown. Western Maryland
Presently holds down first spot with a 2-0-1 slate, followed
by Hampden-Sydney (2-1-0), Randolph-Macon (2-1-1),
and Hopkins (1-1-0).
The Jays can take the title with a tie between H-S
and R-M. Such a situation will leave the Homewood
Squad with a 2-1 record and .667 percentage, while
liampden-Sydney and Western Maryland follow at 2-1-1
(.625), Randolf-Macon trailing with a 2-1-2 (.600) mark.

B.I.A. Desires Candidates
For Board Membership To Host W.Md.

All freshmen interested in becoming members of the Board
of Intramural Athletics are
asked to submit their names to
Bill Ertag, Box 525.
The B.I.A. at Johns Hopkins
, Is composed of three members
from each class, freshmen being
elected in the early spring and
then serving on the Board for
four years. In function, The
Board is a coordinating center
for the Homewood's intramural
athletic programs. In doing so,
the B.I.A. schedules all the various sports, and is the final
authority in cases of protest and
related problems.
The candidates this year will
be elected through an interviewing system in order to give equal
consideration to all. Since, these
interviews will begin shortly, all
candidates are urged to submit
their names at the earliest opportunity.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOV. 20, 1951

G-Burg Defeat Closes Frosh Grid Year
•

By SHELDON STEINBACH

Last Friday afternoon at
Homewood field the Hopkins
freshman football team closed
their season with a nine to six
loss to the Gettysburg College
frosh.
Yearling Coach Bob Scott
called the outcome a moral victory for Hopkins. G-Burg outmanned the Blue Jay squad with
more experience, a heavier line
and speedy backs.
From the opening kick-off
until the beginning of the second half, Gettysburg dominated
play. The first score of the afternoon was set up when a bullet
punt fell dead on the Hopkins
one yard line. A play up the
middle netted no yardage, and
on the next play, quarterback
Hank Schaefer was caught behind the goal line for a two
point safety.

kick. gopkins picked up the ball

down play the pass from Schaefer to halfback Conrad Schwab
was caught out of bounds. From
there Gettysburg took over and
ran out the clock.
The frosh record for the year
was two won, one lost, and one
tie. The victors came over Baltimore Junior College (6-3) and
Franklin and Marshall (28-0).
The tie was with Pennsylvania
Military College (6-6) and the
loss to Gettysburg.
Coach Scott felt this season
had been as equally successful
as those of the past. The Jays
entered the season with a small
squad that lacked experience
and weight..In order to overcome
these deficits they developed
great hustle and competitiveness, which was best exemplified
in the last two games, in which
the opposing lines out-weighed
the Hopkins forwards by twenty
pounds per man.

Kidnapping practices on the
entire Homewood campus were
forbidden by the Student Council in a sweeping decision at
Tuesday's meeting.
A motion to forbid kidnapping
In the dormitories was stated by
Dave Adams and was subsequently amended to include
the entire campus.
The discussion concerning kidnapping was prefaced by a report by Interfraternity Board
President Al Powgermaker in
which he expressed the opinions
put forth by the IFB fraternities
at their Friday meeting. Powdermaker stated that the IFB voted
11-0, with 2 abstentions, in favor
of permitting the continuation of
kidnapping practices.
Three Kidnap
He said that the Board felt
that although only three fraternities—Phi Ep, Beta and DU-still hold kidnapping policies, any
Infringement upon this practice
would necessarily restrict the
freedom of fraternities in the

handling of their pledges as they
see fit. He added that if the Student Council wanted to rule
against kidnapping it would be
"another thing." "It would be impossible to rule out kidnapping
altogether." Powdermaker further
stated that he thought it would
be a good idea to forbid kidnapping in the dorms.
Stu Hanlein, a principal proponent of curbs on kidnapping,
stated the case for the DSRC, of
which he is president. He said,
"what fraternities do with their
pledges is their own business unless they disturb others. I've
lived in the dorms for four years
and I would like quiet. We are
trying to make the dormitory a
home away from home for the
on-campus boys. We can help
100% to make the dorms better
by cutting out kidnapping."
No Respect
"Many fraternity men do not
live in the dormitories," continued Hanlein, "and therefore
have no respect for the dormitory

equipment, property, or quiet.

Political Speeches
Written By Ghosts
Attacked By Long
Clarence D.*Long, Professor of
Political Eccinomy, recently made
newspaper and television history
by calling for politicians "to
adopt a standard of ethics in
their public appearances which
match those they are demanding
from TV quiz shows" by disclosing 'the ghost writers of their
speeches as well as of the books
that made some of them famous."
Continuing the crusade he began in his bid for the Democratic
nomination for U. S. Senator
last year,- Dr. Long went on to
say that the type of ghost writing he had been attacking was
of the variety which found staff
Writers developing ideas, writing
a statement and then issuing it
to the press often without the
candidate even 'seeing it. Dr.
Long went on to say, "When a
political candidate or elected official reads an impressive speech
on inflation or foreign policy,
how many listeners are aware
that he may be completely
ignorant of the issues and may
have just barely read the speech
that his staff writer handed
him?"
On a TV interview Dr. Long
stated he felt that to an extent
the newspapers were responsible
for not giving this issue a bigger
plug while he was running last
year. He felt the papers should
have given him a little more
"moral support" on these points
When questioned as to his possible candidacy in the future Dr.
Long said, that if Nelson Rockefeller still won't say he is running for anything, he thought it
to be too early; any office he
might seek would not come up
for grabs until 1962. Dr. Long
did indicate, however, that he
was still interested in public office.

Foreign Speakers Discuss UN 1961 Examination Schedule
At Cosmopolitan Club Soiree To Be Extended Two Days
On Saturday, November 14 the
Cosmopolitan Club presented a
program of four speakers from
foreign countries who discussed
attitudes towards the United Nations in their respective parts
of the world, and specifically in
their country.
The program, which was presented in cooperation with the
United Nations Association of
Maryland, was entitled "The
U.N.'s Impact 'Round the World."
The main speakers were Leslie
Ronald Aldous of the United
Kingdom, Inder Jitt of India.
Bastiaan Klaverstijn of the
Netherlands, Dr. Norberto de
Ramos of the Philippines, and
Luis Zalamea of Columbia.
Mr. Zalamea, who was the
moderator and a representative
of the United Nations Office of
Public Information, did -not act
in behalf of Columbia but rather
for the United Nations. He explained the purpose of the meeting and the purpose of the U.N.
Fellowship program which was
responsible for the Program. The
Program was organized to help
keep the public informed as to
the U.N.'s activities. Its members
are primarily people connected
With the mass media.
Mr. Aldous, who is the Chief
Officer of the
Information
United Nations Association of

the United Kingdom, was the
first member of the panel to
speak. He did not deal directly
with the question at hand but
discussed, rather, what the
United Nations Association was
doing in the United Kingdom,
The U.N.A.'s main problem was
in trying to break down the existing apathy towards the U.N.
Bastiaan Klaverstijn, an Editor for the Netherlands News
Agency, spoke on his country's
contribution to the U.N. and the
U.N.'s contribution to his country. Acording to Mr. Klaverstijn,
the Netherlands is the third
largest contributor of technical
aid to the U.N. He also pointed
that however large the Netherlands economic contribution was,
they nevertheless have a relatively small impact on world
politics. Unfortunately, the writer
had some difficulty in understanding all of Mr. Klaverstijn's
speech.
Dr. Ramos of the Philippines
is an author, commentator, and
professor. At the present time
he is drafting the first text book
on the United Nations. Because
of language difficulties, the
writer missed much of Dr.
Ramos' speech. However, he did
make the point that the U.N.
had helped to build them up and

that they were now helping to
build up less developed countries.
The last speaker was Mr. Jitt
of India, a correspondent for
"The Times of India." Mr. Jitt
noted that the United Nations is
a part of every-day life in India; and that U.N. beliefs concerning the settlement of its
problems are quite similar to
India's. Mr. Jitt ended by saying
that he thought that the "only
hope for man is in the United
Nations."
A short period of questions
and answers followed during
which most of the questions
posed were in reference to Red
China and whether it should be
admitted to the United Nations.
The feeling of the panelists was
that it should be admitted.

The 1961 January examination
schedule has been lengthened
from the present eight-day
period to a ten-day expanse,
announced Miss Irene Davis, registrar of Johns Hopkins University.

The change was made by Miss
Davis in order to avoid three
consecutive examinations and to
include reading time during the
examination 'period. Since the
1959-60 school schedule was completed when these changes were
suggested, they have been initiated in the 1960-61 school year.
The change has been in the
air sinee last fall when a student delegation met with Miss
Davis; Dr. G. Wilson Shaffer;

Dr William K. Morrill; and Dr.
David Danskin. It was then sug•
gested that a change be made in
order to eliminate the occurrence of three consecutive exams
•

on anyone's schedule.
examination
First - semester
period begins Wednesday, Jan'
uary 27, and concludes Thursday, February 4.
The schedule is aranged 131
a block system. For example, the
examination for all classes which
meet at 8 a.m. Monday, TuesdaY
and Wednesday, are scheduled
at the same time. This holds
true for all classes except foreign
mathematics
and
languages
which each have one test for all
students, which all take at one
time.

When William P. Dugan graduated from
State University of Iowa in 1955, he had
a degree in business administration, a
wife, and a firm resolution to get ahead
in business.
Bill went to work with Northwestern
Bell Telephone Company at Des Moines.
"I wanted to work where I'd find real
opportunities for advancement and get
the training necessary to take advantage
of them," he says."I couldn't have made
a better choice."
Ten months of diversified training
taught Bill the "language" of the business
and gave him the know-how and selfassurance he needed. He was transferred
to the Traffic Department at Cedar Rapids
where he gained experience in operating

room procedures, force scheduling and
training and in supervising operating
personnel. He returned to Des Moines
and in February, 1959, was promoted to
District Traffic Supervisor there.
Today, Bill heads up an organization
of ten supervisory people and about 230
telephone operators who handle approximately 42,000 calls each day. He is also
responsible for auxiliary services such as
Information and the Telephone Company
switchboard.
"This is a booming business," says
Bill."There are new problems coming up
every day to keep my job interesting and
challenging. I don't know where a man
can find more genuine opportunities to
improve himself."

Bill Dugan found the career he was looking for
with a Bell Telephone Company. You might find
yours, too. Talk with the Bell interviewer when
he visits your campus—and read the Bell Tele.
phone booklet on file in your Placement Office.

By STEVE VOORHEES

Exclusion Tactics
The role of the college newspaper is, next to that of
the intellectual and the pervert, the most talked-about yet
least understood subject to rue the minds of undergraduates since the days when Sparta U. dropped its first cadet
colonel.
The main criticism levelled against the News-Letter
has been that its editors form judgments "unqualified
due to a lack of understanding of the situation." However,
the very individuals who so readily voice this view are
in many cases those who insist that certain meetings be
closed wherein important policy decisions directly affecting the undergraduates are made.
As these individuals would have it, the campus newspaper should deteriorate into nothing more than a bulletin
board, tilled with press releases issued at their own discretion which neglect any dissenting opinion.
Formal statements by campus organization men have
the texture of a pre-chewed slice of sugared bread.
Self-government cannot be maintained by clandestine
proceedings. If our so-called "self-government" is to rise
above the level of gross travesty it must welcome all interested students.
The News-Letter does recognize the responsibility
which certain campus leaders fail to see themselves—that
of reporting and commenting honestly upon actions which
involve the student body. Their unjudicious exclusion
policies somehow do not gibe with accusations of neglected
integrity.

AMERICAN LITERATURE:
ITS CAUSE AND CURE
Today, as a service to students of American literature, this'
column presents digests of two classic American novels:
TI1E SCARLET LETTER
by Nathaniel-"Swifty" Hawthorne
This is a heart-rending story of a humble New England lass
named Hester Prynne who is so poor that she does not have
what to eat nor a roof to cover her head. But she is a brave,
brawny girl and she never complains, and by and by her
patience is rewarded: in the summer of 1859 she wins a football
scholarship to Alabama.
•
Hard-working Hester soon wins her letter and everyone says
she is a shoo-in for All-Conference honors, but along comes the
'War Between the States and football, alas, is dropped for the
duration.

- --we

R_

„
She?5boolkrill-Wilfrezte1014;

Poor Hester goes back to New England. It is a bitter cold
winter and poor Hester, alas, does not have any warm clothing
except for her football sweater from Alabama, but that, alas,
has a big scarlet"A" on the front of it and she can hardly wear
such a thing in New England where Union sentiment runs so
high.
Poor Hester, alas, freezes td death.
LITTLE WOMEN
by Louisa May "Bubbles" Alcott
The Marches are a very happy family—and for no discernible
reason. They are poor as snakes; they work from cockcrow to
evensong; their dear old father Philip is away with the Union
armies; and they can't do a thing with their hair.
Still, nothing can dampen the spirits of madcap Meg,jocular
Jo, buoyant Beth, animated Amy, and crazy old Marmee, as
the merry March girls laughingly call their lovable mother.
Well sir, one Christmas the March girls get an invitation to a
ball..They are dying to go because they never have any fun at
all except maybe a few chuckles during the hog-rendering
season. But Beth reminds her sisters that,they ,can hardly go
traipsing off to a ball and leave poor Marmee all alone at
Christmas time. The sisters swear a lot, but they finally agree
with Beth.
Marmee, however, will not hear of it. "Land's sakes, little
women!" she cries. "You must go to the ball and have some
fun. There will be fruit punch and Toll -House cookies and
Early American sandwiches. Best of all, there will be. morris
dancing. Oh, how your father and I used to love that!"
"I never knew father could dance," ories Meg.
"Oh yeah?" cries Marmee. "You should have seen Philip
morris."
"Was Philip a good morriser?" cries Jo.
"The best!" cries Maripee. "Philip could morris in soft pack
or flip-top box and was full of fine, fresh, natura) mildness!"
The girls are cheered to hear this and go to the ball. Marmee
stays home alone, but soon gets a wonderful surprise: Philip
conies back from the war!
When the girls return, from the ball, they find Marmee and
Philip morrising, and they cry "Huzzah!" and throw their poke
bonnets in the air, where they are to this day.

Wooded House

By NELSON DORSEY
The Evergreen House, a large
rambling brick edifice in a 36acre wooded park, has been a
part of the Johns Hopkins University since 1942. Under the
will of John Work Garrett, the
mansion and the grounds at 4545
North Charles Street, his collection of rare maps, books, pamphlets, coins and medals, Oriental ceramics, and most of his
celebrated collection of autographs were left to Hopkins. It
is maintained by the Evergreen
House Foundation, an educational 'trust set up in 1952 by the
will of Alice,Warder Garrett, as
a research library and mUseum
for the benefit of the University
and the people ,of Baltimore.
The main house, a classical
revival structure, was built in
the 1850's. In 1885 a north wing
was erected, joining the house
by an archway. This part became the Far East Room, where
there has been assembled a fine
oollection of Oriental art objects.
Another part became a handsome
little theatre, where amateur
theatricals were given, or friends
were entertained with music.
New - Library
The most important addition
to the house is the "new library"
at the southeast corner of the
mansion overlooking the Italian
garden. This single, lofty chamber shelters 8,700 choice volumes. There are, elsewhere in
the building, more than 26,000
other volumes, not in the rare
book category, but of wide scOpe
and importance. In one classification of books, this room is of
particular interest to students.
This category is in the room devoted to texts on international
law and diplomacy. It includes
all known official source publicaiions on WOrld War I, one of

the few complete collections of
Marten's Treatises:running more
than 100 volumes, and a complete file of the U.S. State Department's official correspondence from the Revolutionary
War to 1940.
Mr. J. W.. Garrett, a Princeton
graduate and U.S. ambassador,
had four general interests: natural history, items dealing with
the beginnings of Maryland, obtaining the signatures of the
signers of the Declaration of
Independence, and collecting
coins. and medals.
Audubon Collection
In the natural history group,
besides huge Audubons and
Goulds, are the flower paintings
of Redoute, and "Natural History of the Carolinas, Florida,
and Bahamas" printed by Catesby in. London in 1771.-The Maryland collection contains 80 of the 130 books and
pamphlets known to have been
printed about this state before
1700.
Sharing the attention with the
diverse wonders of the house is
the complete collection of signatures of the signers of the Declaration of Independence.
Coini and medals are also well
represented in this house-muThe American group
seum.
stretches from our Colonial beginnings to 1940. Among the
early items are Massachusetts
pine-tree shillings of 1652, the
less-known oak and willow shilling& arid a still earlier shilling,
known to antedate 1652.

Sable, Gold Reign
As School Colors
Over Black, Blue
By JOHN FARNHAM
The Johns Hopkins University
has for almost eighty years been
confused over the issue of school
colors. Newcomers see mostly an
Imaginative black and blue enhancing the athletic teams and
school jackets.
After painfully adapting to
the ferocious Hopkins black-and-

blue jay, one never fails to discover that actually the official
colors are sable and gold.
But logic triumphs, and there
actually exists a traceable pattern of thought by which this
whole mess can be settled. Originally, back at the dawn of the
University it was decided to accept the black and sable from
the Hopkins seal which was an
amalgamation of the Lord Baltimore family's coat of arms
(which the state had already
stolen nefariously) and the symbols of scholarship and All

That's Good: the books and terrestial globe.
This was a fine arrangement
for all, until one day during a
Hopkins-Princeton athletic event
—some sort of medieval game
played in those less civilized days
before the invention of modern
non-violent sports—the officials
discovered that no one knew who
was winning or even which team
was going which way. Princetonorange and Hopkins-sable blended rather well, and it was common to see many traumatized
spectators leaving the games.
From this it is easy to see that
the logical change would be from
sable to blue. The Hopkins men
suddenly appeared in black and
blue horizontally-striped jerseys.
This temporarily ended the problems, but someone soon realized
that the new color scheme 'was
closely related to that of the
convicts at the Maryland penitentiary, and the police were on
occasions being completely undone.
-Next vertical stripes were
tested, but this solution became
invalidated with the creation of
referees. By this time nobody
gave a damn what the colors
were. Psychotic color blindness
was a fad.

Milton Gains Post
On US Committee
To Advise Dwight
Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower,
President of the Johns Hopkins
University and expert on Latinaffairs, has been
American
named to an important National
Advisory Committee on InterAmerican Affairs by the President of the United States.
Dr. Eisenhower will serve on
the six-man committee under
the chairmanship of Secretary
of State Christian A. Herter.
In announcing the appointments, President Dwight D.
Eisenhower stated that the committee's creation should serve as
"tangible evidence of the imUnited
the
which
portance
States attaches to relations with
the other American Republics."
Valuable Function
A White House statement released simultaneously said the
President had expressed his conviction that the new committee
"would perform a very helpful
function both in terms of developing useful ideas with re,spect to our Inter-American
Relations and in promoting wider
understanding of these relation§
among the peoples of this country."
Serving on the committee in
addition to Dr. Eisenhower will
be: Walter J. Donnelly, former
t. S. Ambassador to Venezuela
and an executive at the U. S.
in. South
Steel Corporation
America; G. Kenneth Holland.
president of the Institute of International Education; G. A.
Knight, a vice-president of the
AFL-CIO and president of the
Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union; Charles
A. Meyer, a vice-president of
Sears, Roebuck Co.; and Dr.
Dana G. Munro, director of the
Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at
Princeton University.
Miltie's Recommendation
President Eisenhower's authorization of an advisory group
carries out a recommendation of
Dr. Eisenhower in a report following a tour of Latin American
contries .at the President's request last year.
The White House stated that
the committee is in no way related to the current wave of
anti-United States sentiment in
Cuba and Panama, nor the wave
of outbreaks there and throughout Latin America.

It is fitting that the diamond anniversary of football
at Hopkins should be marked by what must be considered
One of the greatest grid squads in that long seventy-five
Year history.
Having clinched the Southern Division Mid-Atlantic
Conference title and set a new school scoring mark with
last week's 47-0 victory over Dickinson, the Jays have
an outside chance to add the Mason-Dixon title to their
laurels with a victory over Western Maryland tomorrow.
The league situation is rather complicated, with four
teams all having a shot at the crown. Western Maryland
Presently holds down first spot with a 2-0-1 slate, followed
by Hampden-Sydney (2-1-0), Randolph-Macon (2-1-1),
and Hopkins (1-1-0).
The Jays can take the title with a tie between H-S
and R-M. Such a situation will leave the Homewood
Squad with a 2-1 record and .667 percentage, while
liampden-Sydney and Western Maryland follow at 2-1-1
(.625), Randolf-Macon trailing with a 2-1-2 (.600) mark.

B.I.A. Desires Candidates
For Board Membership To Host W.Md.

All freshmen interested in becoming members of the Board
of Intramural Athletics are
asked to submit their names to
Bill Ertag, Box 525.
The B.I.A. at Johns Hopkins
, Is composed of three members
from each class, freshmen being
elected in the early spring and
then serving on the Board for
four years. In function, The
Board is a coordinating center
for the Homewood's intramural
athletic programs. In doing so,
the B.I.A. schedules all the various sports, and is the final
authority in cases of protest and
related problems.
The candidates this year will
be elected through an interviewing system in order to give equal
consideration to all. Since, these
interviews will begin shortly, all
candidates are urged to submit
their names at the earliest opportunity.

By SHELDON STEINBACH

Last Friday afternoon at
Homewood field the Hopkins
freshman football team closed
their season with a nine to six
loss to the Gettysburg College
frosh.
Yearling Coach Bob Scott
called the outcome a moral victory for Hopkins. G-Burg outmanned the Blue Jay squad with
more experience, a heavier line
and speedy backs.
From the opening kick-off
until the beginning of the second half, Gettysburg dominated
play. The first score of the afternoon was set up when a bullet
punt fell dead on the Hopkins
one yard line. A play up the
middle netted no yardage, and
on the next play, quarterback
Hank Schaefer was caught behind the goal line for a two
point safety.

Military College (6-6) and the
